properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long duration heat event is expected. Daytime high temperatures near thirty with overnight lows near 18 are expected for the foreseeable future. Please refer to your public forecast for further details on expected temperatures. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the Air Quality Health Index to approach the high risk category. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-01T07:17:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-30T15:18:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0881137853.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy rain is possible for parts of northern Alberta starting tonight. A developing low pressure system in southern Alberta will bring rain, at times heavy, to parts of northwestern Alberta by this evening. Total rainfall amounts are expected to approach 50 mm by the time rainfall tapers off Thursday morning. Presently confidence is low for exactly where the heaviest rain will fall. Rainfall warnings have been issued for parts of west-central Alberta and may be expanded as the system develops. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-01T08:36:53-00:00

Overnight lows near 18 are expected providing little relief from the heat. Please refer to your public forecast for further details on expected temperatures. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the Air Quality Health Index to approach the high risk category. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Summary:

Heat warnings are issued when very high temperature or humidity conditions are expected to pose an elevated risk of heat illnesses, such as heat stroke or heat exhaustion. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: High Water Advisory Is Being Issued For The Whitemud River.
properties.Summary:
Description: This is a Manitoba Emergency Alert. Manitoba Infrastructure’s Hydrologic Forecast Centre has issued a High Water Advisory for the Whitemud River. If you are in the affected area, be watchful as local waterways are expected to rise quickly and may cause flooding. There is a potential for overland flooding in low lying areas. Do not attempt to cross fast flowing waters or waters of unknown depth. Use caution when driving on all roads as road conditions may have changed. Avoid flooded areas. Follow all directions by local authorities, listen for updates and take all necessary precautions to stay safe. Stay tuned to local media for updates.
Expires: 2020-07-02T16:00:00-05:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization, 2020-06-30T16:00:38-05:00, 11FF514C-4F18-A3CB-BA89-07F2861F8F84
Area: Whitemud River
properties.Author: Manitoba Emergency Measures Organization

properties.Title: Severe Thunderstorm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of dangerous thunderstorms that may be capable of producing damaging wind gusts, damaging hail and torrential rain. Severe thunderstorms associated with a low pressure system currently in North Dakota are pushing northwards into Canada this afternoon. Large hail, torrential downpours and damaging wind gusts will be associated with the strongest of these thunderstorms. The threat of severe weather will begin to push eastward tonight as the low pressure system evolves. ### Very large hail can damage property, break windows, dent vehicles and cause serious injury. Very strong wind gusts can damage buildings, down trees and blow large vehicles off the road. Remember, severe thunderstorms can produce tornadoes. Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Severe thunderstorm watches are issued when atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of thunderstorms that could produce one or more of the following: large hail, damaging winds, torrential rainfall. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-01T06:59:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-30T18:26:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0568374342.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy rain for BC Peace River and Fort Nelson on Wednesday and Thursday. Current guidance suggests 40 to 80 mm of rain is possible through Thursday, with the higher rainfall amounts expected over the mountains. However, there remains some uncertainty about just how much rain will fall during this prolonged event. A low pressure system will develop over Southern Alberta today and then intensify as it moves northward into Northern Alberta by Wednesday evening. The system will funnel rain onto the eastern slopes of the Rocky Mountains. BC South Peace River Showers will begin to fall over the BC South Peace River Region including Dawson Creek and Chetwynd by this afternoon. These showers will slowly transition into rain by Wednesday morning and rain, heavy at times, by Wednesday night. The rain, heavy at times, will taper off on Thursday morning, but showers will persist into Friday. BC North Peace River For BC North Peace River, including Fort St. John, the showers will start midday Wednesday. The light rain will change to rain, heavy at times, by mid afternoon and continue until Thursday evening. Fort Nelson Region Southern portions of the Fort Nelson Region can expect periods of rain to continue from tonight through Friday with heavier rain falling early Thursday morning. The community of Fort Nelson will see isolated showers until early Thursday morning when rain, heavy at times, will begin. This rain will taper off early Thursday afternoon. Rainfall warnings may be issued as the system further develops and confidence in rainfall amounts increases. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-01T09:40:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-30T17:41:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0919722098.2020
Area: B.C. South Peace River, B.C. North Peace River, Fort Nelson
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Humidex values reaching 38 are expected. One more evening of warm temperatures can be expected before a cold front sweeps through later tonight, bringing thunderstorms to much of the area along with somewhat cooler temperatures for Canada Day. The respite will be short-lived with temperatures are expected to climb to around the 30 mark again on Thursday. ### The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. For more information on heat and your health: - Visit Manitoba Health at: http://www.manitoba.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/heat.html. - Call Health Links – Info Santé at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-01T12:49:01-00:00

properties.Title: Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of squalls with wind gusts up to 40 knots. A cold front will track across southern Manitoba tonight. A line of strong thunderstorms will accompany this front and produce very strong winds gusts that may reach 40 knots. These storms are likely over Lake Manitoba late this evening and ending overnight. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.
Expires: 2020-07-01T12:29:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-30T20:30:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2404860659.2020
Area: Lake Manitoba
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A heat event is expected through Thursday. Daytime high temperatures in the low thirties with overnight lows near 18 are expected to continue until Thursday. Cooler air will move into the region Thursday night. Please refer to your public forecast for further details on expected temperatures. Hot and humid air can also bring deteriorating air quality and can result in the air quality health index to approach the high risk category. ### Extreme heat affects everyone. The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. Watch for the effects of heat illness: swelling, rash, cramps, fainting, heat exhaustion, heat stroke and the worsening of some health conditions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-01T11:49:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-30T19:50:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0967583675.2020
Area: Geraldton - Longlac - Caramat, Manitouwadge - Hornepayne, Fraserdale - Pledger Lake, Kapuskasing - Hearst - Smooth Rock Falls
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Heat Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Humidex values reaching 38 are expected. One more evening of warm temperatures can be expected before a cold front sweeps through later tonight, bringing thunderstorms to much of the area along with somewhat cooler temperatures for Canada Day. The respite will be short-lived with temperatures are expected to climb to around the 30 mark again on Thursday. ### The risks are greater for young children, pregnant women, older adults, people with chronic illnesses and people working or exercising outdoors. For more information on heat and your health: - Visit Manitoba Health at: http://www.manitoba.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/heat.html. - Call Health Links – Info Santé at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-07-01T12:49:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-06-30T20:50:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0418737140.2020
Area: Oxford House and Gods Lake, Red Sucker Lake, Island Lake
